post_text:
Today, Joshua Tree Elementary School was presented with $2,000 in gift cards from the Sheriff's Employees' Benefit Association (SEBA).

The Sheriff's Employees' Benefit Association in partnership with The San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schools choose 10 schools in San Bernardino County to present with gift cards. The gift cards will be distributed to teachers at each of the chosen school sites to purchase classroom materials. Teachers who received the cards will then be able to submit photos of the creative ways they chose to spend the gift cards.

â€œOur partners in Law Enforcement set the bar for community service,â€ said Tom Baumgarten, Superintendent, MUSD. â€œWe are honored that one of our schools was chosen to receive this generous gift from the Sheriff's Employees' Benefit Association, and it will greatly impact the lives of our students and teachers.â€ San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department SEBA

post_text:
Superintendent Baumgarten was on hand assisting Nutritional Services as they kicked off the new school year of meal distributions.

Meals will be distributed every Thursday at all school sites, with the exception of Black Rock High School from 9:00 am - 10:30 am. There is also a new evening pick up time available from 5:00 pm - 6:00 pm at Yucca Valley High School and Twentynine Palms Elementary.

post_text:
Morongo Unified School District will resume distance learning/independent study education on August 26th for the 2020/2021 school year.

Superintendent Tom Baumgarten will be answering your questions on a Facebook Live with the Hi-Desert Star, Monday, August 17th at 2:00 pm.

Have questions? You can submit them in advance by asking them in the comment section of this post, or ask them during the Facebook Live. The event will be live on The Hi-Desert Star Facebook page.

https://www.facebook.com/hidesertstar

post_text:
A big thank you to everyone who took part in todays Backpack Giveaway held at the Sportsman's Club in Joshua Tree.

Students were able to receive backpack's with school supplies, so they are ready to go for school.

Thank you again to the sponsors and volunteers from JT Sportsmans Club, San Bernardino County Schools, Morongo Basin Sexual Assault Services and Morongo Basin Sheriff's Station.

post_text:
SCHOOL FUNDING DATA COLLECTION FORM

Dear Parent/Guardian:

Morongo Unified School District is requesting you complete the School Funding Data Collection Form online. This form will replace the Online Meal Benefit Application. Your application could help increase funding for our schools. We urge each family to complete this form.

You may start applying electronically on our district website BEGINNING AUGUST 1, 2020, by following these easy instructions:

1. Go to https://mealapp.morongousd.com
2. Enter your information and click SUBMIT
If you experience any difficulties completing the On-Line form, or would like a paper form, please call us at (760)367.9191 ext. 4263 or 4271.

We look forward to a unique, but great 2020-2021 school year serving your child(ren).

Janet Barth, SNS
Director, Nutritional Services

Yesterday was another successful day of meal distribution to families in the Morongo Basin.

Twentynine Palms Elementary School was able to distribute the weekly meals along with the Farmers to Families 20lbs protein boxes. The district was pleased to have the help of local Marines during the distribution, along with Morongo Basin Community Health who distributed dental packs to families.

Dear Parents/Guardians:

The Morongo Unified School District is committed to providing a quality education to all its students in an environment that is as safe as possible for all students and staff members. In order to do this, it is the Districtâ€™s goal to offer a variety of educational options. It is vital that we gather as much information as we possibly can so we can plan how to best use our resources. Please take the time to complete a Pre-Registration Questionnaire for each of your students. Links to this document, titled â€œMUSD Return to School Survey 2020-21â€ can be found below, on your school website, on the District website, and on the MUSD Facebook page.

Please go online as soon as possible and complete this important document. Thank you for your help.

Don't forget, today at Yucca Valley High School meal distribution includes USDA Farmers to Families Protein Boxes, as well as, goody bags being handed out by San Bernardino Department of Public Health.

The goody bags include "Shape of Yoga" booklets, recipes, stickers, games and coloring sheets.

A big thank you to MUSD Nutritional Services who continue to serve the community, San Bernardino Department of Public Health and the number of student and other volunteers that help make these days possible.

post_text:
REMINDER: Due to Coronavirus (COVID-19), children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals at school will get extra food benefits. These food benefits are called Pandemic EBT or P-EBT benefits.

P-EBT benefits help families in California buy food when schools are closed because of the coronavirus emergency.

Families will get up to $365 per eligible child on their P-EBT card to use on food and groceries.

Families with children who get CalFresh, Medi-Cal or Foster Care benefits do not need to apply. Most will get their P-EBT card in the mail during the month of May.

The deadline to apply has been extended to July 15th.

DOUG WELLER NAMED TEMPORARY ACTING SUPERINENDENT

In a unanimous vote the Morongo Unified School District Board of Education named Doug Weller as Temporary Acting Superintendent.

Morongo Unified School District Superintendent Tom Baumgarten has taken a temporary leave of absence. â€œIt is important during this time that we have someone in place to oversee the day to day operations of the district during the budget planning for next year, and to help lead the district through the planning stages of re-opening the schools at the end of summer,â€ stated L Hilary Slotta, President, Board of Education.

Doug Weller, former Asst. Superintendent, Human Resources has a long history with the district that also includes positions in teaching and school site principal. Mike Ghelber said that, â€œThe Board of Education believes that Dougâ€™s knowledge and experience within the district will help guide us during Mr. Baumgartenâ€™s absence.â€

post_text:
Due to Coronavirus (COVID-19), children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals at school (ğ‘¨ğ’ğ’ ğ‘´ğ‘¼ğ‘ºğ‘« ğ‘ºğ’•ğ’–ğ’…ğ’†ğ’ğ’•ğ’”) will get extra food benefits. These food benefits are called Pandemic EBT or P-EBT benefits.
P-EBT benefits help families in California buy food when schools are closed because of the coronavirus emergency.

Families will get up to $365 per eligible child on their P-EBT card to use on food and groceries.

Families with children who get CalFresh, Medi-Cal or Foster Care benefits do not need to apply. Most will get their P-EBT card in the mail during the month of May. P-EBT cards will begin arriving around May 12, 2020.

Families with children who are eligible for free or reduced-price meals and who do not get their P-EBT card in the mail by about May 22, 2020 must apply online before June 30, 2020. The online application will be available beginning May 22, 2020 at the link below.
shared_text:
CDSS.CA.GOV
Pandemic EBT

Thank you for your partnership in your child's education. We would like to inform you of a helpful resource that has been created for you

Universal Design for Learning (UDL) is a framework with guidelines for assisting your child in reducing barriers to the content of your child's learning. The three useful websites with the UDL specific resources have been placed on the Morongo Unified School District website, under the Exploratory Education link. Parents may click on the tab called â€œUDL Resources for Parentsâ€ to access them.

We recommend that you looking through the information to assist your child.

Thank you for the continued dedication and commitment to the education of your child. We appreciate your partnership and look forward to our future journey together.

post_text:
The City of 29 Palms Park and Recreation Department recently continued the tradition of recognizing an 8th grade boy and girl for the Hugh "Chief" Jones and Dana Casey Awards.

The recipients of these awards are those who not only have amazing athletic ability, but just as importantly, display outstanding sportsmanship on and off the court.

This years winners are Luke Sidhu and Sydnei Rahn. Not only was Luke the best player on the court, but he is a model citizen off it. Luke's selfless attitude, combined with his performance in school and integrity earned him this honor.

Sydnei is a gifted athlete, but what stands out the most is her personality. Constantly making those around her smile and laugh, Sydnei embodies the teammate everyone enjoys playing with. Leaders on the court, and in school, Sydnei and Luke should be acknowledged for their altruistic nature and athletic accomplishments.

The perpetual trophies are displayed at the Twentynine Palms Junior High School, where their names will be engraved alongside previous winners.

post_text:
Did you know tomorrow, May, 1st is School Lunch Hero Day?

â€œSchool nutrition employees must balance many roles and follow numerous federal, state and local regulations to ensure safe and healthy meals are available in schools. School Lunch Hero Day provides the opportunity for the community to thank these hardworking heroesâ€ said Janet Barth, Director of Nutritional Services.

Federal nutrition standards ensure that school cafeterias always offer low-fat or fat-free milk, fruits, vegetables, whole grains and lean protein. School meals also meet limits on calories, sodium and unhealthy fats.

The incredible Morongo Unified Nutritional Services staff, serves approximately 2 million meals each year. Thank you School Lunch Heroes!

MUSD BOARD OF EDUCATION APPROVES COVID-19 GRADING POLICY

At the regular scheduled MUSD Board of Education Meeting held on April 28, 2020, the Board of Education approved the districts new COVID-19 Grading Policy.

The grading policy will be enacted for the spring semester of the 2019-2020 school year. ğ€ğ¬ğ¬ğ¢ğ ğ§ğ¦ğğ§ğ­ğ¬ ğ­ğ¡ğšğ­ ğšğ«ğ ğ ğ«ğšğğğ ğ°ğ¢ğ¥ğ¥ ğ¨ğ§ğ¥ğ² ğ›ğ ğ®ğ¬ğğ ğ­ğ¨ ğ¢ğ§ğœğ«ğğšğ¬ğ ğš ğ¬ğ­ğ®ğğğ§ğ­â€™ğ¬ ğ ğ«ğšğğ. ğ“ğ¡ğ ğŸğ¢ğ§ğšğ¥ ğ¬ğğœğ¨ğ§ğ ğ¬ğğ¦ğğ¬ğ­ğğ« ğ ğ«ğšğğ ğœğšğ§ ğ§ğğ¯ğğ« ğ ğ¨ ğ›ğğ¥ğ¨ğ° ğ­ğ¡ğ ğ ğ«ğšğğ ğğšğ«ğ§ğğ ğšğ¬ ğ¨ğŸ ğŒğšğ«ğœğ¡ ğŸğŸ‘ğ­ğ¡, the day of the school closure.

Teachers will begin to grade Google Classroom assignments beginning May 4th. The last day an assignment will be graded is May 29th. All assignments will be recorded as Extra Credit so that all points earned by a students will have the effect of raising their current grade.

Please see the following documents for the following three options for increasing or recording final grades for the spring semester of 2020 amidst the global Covid-19 pandemic;

MAGTF Training Command/Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center at 29 Palms
April 15 at 10:30 AM Â·

Encouragement

U.S. Marines with the Provost Marshals Office, Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center, Twentynine Palms, Calif. and staff of Condor Elementary School, Morongo Unified School District, participate in a parade of cars at the base, April 10, 2020. The teachers and staff of Condor Elementary hosted the parade to show support to their students who were confined to their homes during the COVID-19 crisis. (U.S. Marine Corps video by Lance Cpl. Gustavo Romero)

ğƒğğšğ« ğ‚ğ¥ğšğ¬ğ¬ ğ¨ğŸ ğŸğŸğŸğŸ ğšğ§ğ ğ­ğ¡ğğ¢ğ« ğŸğšğ¦ğ¢ğ¥ğ¢ğğ¬:

We know that you have many questions about your upcoming graduation, which has been impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic. Your high school principals will work with your senior class advisor or the Associated Student Body advisor to gather ideas and input from your peers to conduct a meaningful event under the current restrictions.

Please share your creative ideas with the ASB representatives on your campus on how to celebrate this event in a way that complies with the social distancing guidelines and restrictions on gatherings. The top two ideas presented by the student leadership groups will then be voted on by the graduating seniors.

Should the current situation change, and we are allowed to relax the social distancing requirement, we will then be able to consider other options at that time. Thank you for showing the resiliency and courage to move forward in these challenging times.

post_text:
Congratulations to Twentynine Palms High School senior Dejejuanice (Deje) Brewer, the 2020 Greenleaf Scholarship winner.

An amazing job by the other four finalists as well, Anwyn Hilderbrand and Anthony Rodriguez Rojas from Yucca Valley High School, and Diego Hernandez and Teagan Thompson from 29 Palms High School!
shared_text:
Copper Mountain College Foundation
March 31 at 6:10 PM Â·

Copper Mountain College Foundation is proud to announce Dejejuanice (Deje) Brewer of Twentynine Palms as the 2020 Greenleaf Scholarship winner.

Through a rigorous application process, Brewer along with four other finalists, Anwyn Hilderbrand and Anthony Rodriguez Rojas from Yucca Valley High School, and Diego Hernandez and Teagan Thompson from 29 Palms High School showed their stellar character in written and oral interviews. THANK YOU ALL FOR YOUR THOUGHTFUL INTERVIEWS AND YOUR FLEXIBILITY IN THIS PROCESS! Our future is bright! #IGotMyStartAtCMC #CopperMountainCollege #JoshuaTree #TPHS #WeareYVHS #FightingCacti #Thisiswhatcmcfoundationdoes #greenleafscholars

Did you know that April is the Month of the Military Child? It is a time to honor the sacrifices made by military families worldwide, with an emphasis on the experience of the dependent children of military members serving at home and overseas.

Even though school is not currently in session, Condor Elementary School wanted to make sure their students still felt special. The school staff handed out special gifts to their students during the Nutritional pick-up. Way to go Condor!

Dear Parents, Guardians, and Students:

After working with fellow superintendents in the 33 districts in the county, as well as the county superintendent of schools, we will be ğğ±ğ­ğğ§ğğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ­ğ¡ğ ğœğ¥ğ¨ğ¬ğ®ğ«ğ ğ¨ğŸ ğŒğ¨ğ«ğ¨ğ§ğ ğ¨ ğ”ğ§ğ¢ğŸğ¢ğğ ğ’ğœğ¡ğ¨ğ¨ğ¥ ğƒğ¢ğ¬ğ­ğ«ğ¢ğœğ­ ğ¬ğœğ¡ğ¨ğ¨ğ¥ğ¬ ğ­ğ¡ğ«ğ¨ğ®ğ ğ¡ ğ…ğ«ğ¢ğğšğ², ğŒğšğ² ğŸ, ğŸğŸğŸğŸ.

The district will continue to support our students with both instruction and nutrition to the extent feasible. While we have many talented educators across the basin, we will all be learning how to best support students to stay engaged academically.

For the time being, please visit our resources and review our frequently asked question page located on our website http://www.morongo.k12.ca.us as well as the district Facebook page.

High School students at Twentynine Palms High School and Yucca Valley High School got the opportunity to look towards their futures this morning.

Today, the Annual Career Exploration Day was held at Twentynine Palms High School. This event is held annually, and alternated between high schools. The event is put on by the staff and students of the Transition Partnership Program and WorkAbility I, programs that offer career exploration guidance and an opportunity to participate in subsidized employment to participating students.

This years event had over 80 career paths for students to explore that included military options, police, fire, a variety of medical fields, trade programs, grocery, sales, technology and many more.

post_text:
Did you know that today, March 2nd is National Read Across America Day? Its a day when schools across America celebrate our favorite activity, reading.

The day was first established by the National Education Association (NEA) in 1998 to help get kids excited about reading. The day occurs each year on the birthday of beloved childrenâ€™s book author Dr. Seuss.

This week schools throughout the district will be celebrating all week long with fun activities, read-a-thons and special guest readers in class.

post_text:
This year, the Morongo Unified School District, in partnership with Waste Not Morongo Basin, is piloting a food rescue program.

The program includes sharing tables for students, and donating unused food to local food banks, and other charitable organizations. Committed to preventing hunger, and reducing waste, five school sites are piloting the food rescue program, which was implemented September 16, 2019. Sites chosen for the pilot program include: Onaga Elementary School, Palm Vista Elementary School, Twentynine Palms Elementary School, Twentynine Palms Junior High School, and Yucca Valley Elementary School. Reach Out Morongo, Food 4 Life Ministries, and Unity Home pick up and distribute all donated foods.

For the month of October over 240 pounds of fruits and veggies, 1600 pints of milk, and 800 cartons of juice were donated.

shared_text:
Mojave Desert Land Trust
February 25 at 6:01 PM Â·

A big thanks to the students from Black Rock High School for their hard work today cleaning up Section 33, one of our properties in Joshua Tree. The 19 students were helped along by AmeriCorps NCCC - and the results were amazing. A lot of trash got hauled away! Section 33 is a square mile property with beautiful views of the National Park, but it gets lots of windblown trash and littering. Black Rock is actually located close to this land, and we were thrilled that they wanted to take part in this volunteer opportunity.
Photos: Cindy Holland/MDLT

Congratulations to Black Rock High School on their recognition as a Model Continuation High School (MCHS) for 2020 by State Superintendent of Public Instruction (SSPI) Tony Thurmond.

The Model Continuation High School (MCHS) Recognition Program identifies and recognizes outstanding programs. These schools provide comprehensive services to at-risk youth through the use of exemplary instructional strategies, flexible scheduling, and guidance and counseling services. post_text:
Congratulations to a group of La Contenta Middle School 8th grade students recently placed in the top 3 in the Mojave Water Agencyâ€™s Curiosity Quest Problem Solvers.

The Eight LCMS Middle School students participated in the Mojave Water Agency's competition, in conjunction with PBS' Curiosity Quest Problem Solvers. Students were required to developed and presented a conceptual product to reduce water consumption.

The students traveled to the Apple Valley competition on three separate days over the course of five months with the hope of developing the winning product concept. LCMS students came up with the idea of an in-home water conservation system that tracks water consumption through sensors and relays real-time information to a smart phone app.

The LCMS student group presented their idea to a panel of industry judges and the results of the competition were revealed at the Feb. 14th Water Summit in Victorville, CA. LCMS made it to the top three, along with two other high-desert high schools, and ultimately walked away with a first place finish and a $3,000 check for their school

post_text:
This semester, both MUSD students along with Adult Learners are participating in the Pharmacy Clerk course offered through the Academy of College and Career Excellence.

The Pharmacy Clerk is program, is a dual-purpose course, serving as an introduction to Pharmacy Technician and providing the foundation for most careers in Pharmacology.

Students who complete the Pharmacy Clerk course, will acquire the basic knowledge and skills necessary to be employed as a Pharmacy Assistant clerk. Students are introduced to the roles, responsibilities, and educational requirements for a career in pharmacology, while acquiring basic knowledge in HIPAA regulations, infection control, medical terminology, and diseases as it relates to pharmacology.

Did you know that the MUSD Academy of College and Career Excellence offers career technical education classes that are free and open to the public?

One of those course, is the 911 Dispatcher course. This course provides an overview of the eligibility and training standards required for 9-1-1-Communications. Students in the course gain practical experience in the area of law enforcement communications, telephone/technology procedures, regulations and reports for missing persons, domestic abuse, child and elder abuse, hate crimes as well as communications responsibility related to community policing and cultural diversity.

T-K students in Mrs. Plunketts class at Joshua Tree Elementary School spent the afternoon learning all about the Lunar New Year.

Students in the class got to decorate their own dragons, and then parade them through the halls to help scare away winter. They checked outside at the end of the parade and the sun was shining bright. Way to go Owls! Joshua Tree Elementary School

post_text:
Oasis Elementary Schools after school programs recently hosted a visit by Amy Woods, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services.

The school has a variety of afterschool programs that are well attended by students.

Students in the GATE program planned and built a model city constructed out of recycled material. Students then presented a power point to Ms. Woods and parents about the economics of the city and its laws.

An additional after school program helps struggling students improve academically. A large part of the program consists of enrichment activities including art, readers theatre, and Ozo bot programing. Students shared their projects with Ms. Woods who also addressed both groups of students and parents sharing the importance of technology and how the skills students are learning now will be utilized at the secondary level at MUSD.

This year students at Yucca Valley High School get the opportunity to take a Dual Enrollment Spanish class, earning them both high school and college credits through Copper Mountain College.

The intent of the Dual Enrollment classes, is to provide an enhanced educational opportunity for students who are capable of â€œadvanced scholastic or vocational work.â€

In DE Spanish, students incorporate music into their daily oral language activities. In honor of Dr. King and Black History Month, their songs this month feature afro-latina artists from a variety of Spanish Speaking countries. Students sing, in order to improve fluency, comprehension and pronunciation at the beginning of each class.

post_text:
Yucca Valley High School's E-Sports club completed its inaugural season with a 7-7 record after a difficult start against the likes of Mater Dei HS and other powerhouse E-Sports teams.

The YVHS E-Sports team was comprised of five dedicated players competing in League of Legends: Blake Cormack, Hilkia Sulistyono, Chi Cunningham, Alec Hadley, Tim Cruz.

Legion: Gaming Lounge owner, Eddie Costello, hosted the club for all practices and competition days. The use of the gaming lounge allowed the club to quickly hit the ground running and participate in the inaugural fall PlayVS sports season.

YVHS E-Sports will be quickly transitioning to a two sport team with the inclusion of Rocket League in during the spring season. The PlayVS spring season is set to kick off on February 17th, with a registration deadline of January 31st. Any interested players for the spring season are asked to contact Athletic Director Wright or Mr. Bolt. #WeAreYV

post_text:
This year the 64 members of the Yucca Valley High School National Honor Society have been working hard to plan and carry out 33 separate service projects. In addition students are performing community service hours with numerous charitable organizations in the Morongo Basin, that support their growth according to the four pillars of NHS: Scholarship, Leadership, Service, and Character.

Some of their recent work includes:
Hosting events at the Boys and Girls Club to make snowflake crafts and decorate cookies with children.

In November, one of our members worked with Mojave Desert Land Trust to plan an event and build a group of over 50 volunteers to build a rock gabion wall at the MDLT facility.

In December, students organize a toy drive to donate to the program at Yucca Valley Elementary School that helps families in need with gifts for children. Way to go Trojans. #WeAreYV

post_text:
Morongo Unified School District has opened additional registration in to the Transitional Kindergarten program at Yucca Valley Elementary School, for the 2019/2020 school year with classes possibly starting second semester, pending enrollment.

Registration for this program is free and open to students who turned 5 between the dates of September 2 and December 2, 2019. Students are welcome from all attendance zones for this program and Yucca Valley elementary School does not need to be your home school. The program runs from 9:40 am to 1:40 pm, and each student in the program will be provided with free breakfast and lunch each day. Transportation is not included for this program.

If you have a qualified child you are interested in enrolling, please call Yucca Valley Elementary School at (760) 365-3381 or email celeste.wahlberg@moronog.k12.ca.us. Spaces for this program are limited.

The Learning Center at Palm Vista Elementary provides flexibility and options for serving all students in need of extra support.

The Learning Center Helps benefits students who need supplemental, targeted, small group intervention to students with IEPs. The Lab allows students to receive instruction within the least restrictive environment to meet their individual learning needs.

Did you know that school libraries are fundamental to developing engaged student readers who have the capability and inclination to read and learn beyond their years at school?

School libraries help students learn to find and use the information they need, to succeed now and in their future life and work.

Kindergarteners at Palm Vista Elementary School enjoy their weekly trip to the library where they get to listen intently to stories from the Librarian and choose books of their own for the week. Palm Vista Panthers PTO

post_text:
Today Yucca Valley Elementary School kicked off their second round of PBIS (Positive Behavioral Interventions and Support)Camps.

Students at the school are eligible to participate if they have had 95% attendance and no more than 3 minor incidents and no major incidents (referrals). There were 343 students who qualified.

This round of camps includes Volleyball and Dance Camp. A big thank you to the Yucca Valley High School Volleyball girls and Starstruck Dance Studio who came out to help lead the students in their camps!

Students at a number of schools throughout the district get the opportunity to partner with Spark Growth Program throughout the school year.

Yesterday 2nd & 3rd grade students at Yucca Mesa Elementary School got to work on a project that focused on Social Emotional Learning.

Students got to listen to the book We're All Wonders, and then discussed empathy and how changing your perspective can change how you feel.Students then worked on an art project that allowed them to choose words and describe how they are wonders. Thank you Spark Growth Program for all of your hours spent with students! Ymes Roadrunners

post_text:
Kindergarten students in Mrs. Estes class at Yucca Mesa Elementary School are getting to implement hands on technology in a number of exciting ways.

Students in the class get the opportunity to share their work and messages with their parents through the Seesaw app, creating a powerful learning loop between teachers, students, and their families. Students take photos of their work and upload it to the app with a recorded message.

Kindergartners are also utilizing Ozobots and code.org as a way to learn simple coding and how to program robots. The two programs inspire students to go from consuming technology to creating it. Way to go Roadrunners! Ymes Roadrunners

Students participating in the GATE program at Yucca Mesa Elementary School are getting the opportunity this semester to work on a Design & Building Project.

Students are building a model school site by incorporating information gained from interviewing students and staff, hearing from local contractors and working on blue prints. Students will then work together to build a 3-D model of the finished project. Way to go Roadrunners, we can't wait to see the finished project! Ymes Roadrunners

post_text:
This year, Yucca Mesa Elementary School is a new Unified Champion School. The school is piloting a Unified PE class taught by Adam Schilling (PE Teacher) and Angela Gay (Adapted PE Specialist) along with other school wide activities to promote inclusion.

The Unified PE class, partners students from grades K-6 with and without disabilities in a PE class showing everyone is Unified and very little difference between them, emphasizing inclusion for all.

Yucca Mesa Elementary school is the first elementary school in the district to add this program. Yucca Mesa has always promoted inclusion for all students, but this program gives them a title of Unified Champion School, as well as, a grant from Special Olympics.

This program has been a huge success, and the smiles on everyoneâ€™s faces during class says it all. Ymes Roadrunners

post_text:
REMINDER: Join Morongo Unified School District on January 8th, in a Round-Table discussion on Anti- Bullying.

Attendees will participate in small group discussion that will rotate every 15 minutes. At each table, invited participants will include a mixed group of principals, mental health experts, Board of Education members, students and classroom teachers.

Each table will have a topic talking point related to bullying designed to initiate conversation, discussion, problem solving and concerns on that topic. Each participant will have the opportunity to visit each table and engage with that topic.

post_text:
Students at the West end of the District held the first MUSD Youth Court hearings last weeks.

MUSD Youth Court works to find alternative means of correction in lieu of suspension. Students who participate in the Youth Court process, allows peers to help counsel and establish restorative practices for first time offenders in an effort to keep them positively engaged in school.

The MUSD Youth Court, is run in conjunction with the Sheriff's department and the office of the District Attorney, who worked with MUSD students to train and administer this alternative to school discipline. The MUSD Youth Court is comprised of students from Yucca Valley High School, Twentynine Palms High School, La Contenta Middle School and Twentynine Palms Junior High School.

The school's volunteers hosted a day of holiday themed activities for students, that allowed parents to finish up their holiday shopping. Students go to decorate cookies, arts and crafts, a visit with Santa and much more.

Sixth grade students volunteered their time to help at the event where money earned will go towards their sixth grade science camp. Palm Vista Panthers PTO

post_text:
Twentynine Palms Junior High School is keeping with the theme of Twentynine Palms, An Oasis of Murals, the school has historically added a number of murals around campus.

As part of a science project years ago, one of the science classes painted a mural of our solar system to scale. Now that the campus has moved toward a more campus-wide STEAM culture, students wanted to create a new mural for the wall encompassing all aspects of Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, and Math.

Former teacher Mr. Jefferies, helped get the initiative going with his art class. Recently Mr. Schmit has been working with specific classes to add something to mural each year. This year, students are picking up where last yearâ€™s class left off, by painting TPJHS using binary coding. Students Jenica Silvas and April Smith, are heading up this years project and will add another yet to be determined picture to the mural in the spring. Twentynine Palms Junior High School

post_text:
A number of students throughout the District were able to participate in the "Measure your Taste Buds Event" today.
The event, put on by Nutritional Services, hosted 13 vendors, showcasing over 40 food items.

In attendance were YVHS culinary students and Joshua Tree Elementary 4, 5, and 6th graders; a total of 96 MUSD students. Superintendent Tom Baumgarten, Board of Education President Hilary Slotta, and Sharon Flores, Assistant Superintendent Business Services also participated in the event, tasting items with the students.

The results of the student ratings will determine which new items to add to the breakfast, lunch, and supper menus.

post_text:
Students in Mr. Seacat's Creative and Expository Writing Class at Twentynine Palms Junior High School have been working together through a community building circle.

The community building circle is designed to help develop trust, empathy and connectivity among the students and teacher. They also use it to analyze stories, brainstorm for new ideas, and discuss issues that are happening on campus.

The classes current project, is going to be an online newspaper/blog. It has three components: issues at TPJHS, local,national and global news stories, and an OP-ED section.

post_text:
Parents: Yucca Valley High School conducted a shelter in place today following a report of an incident in the Yucca Valley community.

The incident, handled by law enforcement, happened more than a mile from the campus.

In an effort to be safe, the campus ordered a shelter in place. The purpose of a shelter in place is to eliminate movement around campus. Educational activities continue during the period of a shelter in place.

Different than a lock down during which all activities cease and the campus is completely secured, a shelter in place is designed to prevent any unnecessary impact to the site when a situation in the community takes place. The shelter in place has now been lifted.

post_text:
Congratulations to Twentynine Palms Junior High School Counselor Jackie Brandt for her recognition by the California League of Middle Schools as a VIP Educator of the Year.

Jackie Brandt has been the counselor at TPJHS for the past 20 years. Mrs. Brandt is a natural leader, dedicated to the well-being of all students, collaborates with and supports students, families and staff, and demonstrates enthusiasm and proactivity through her support of the school mission and vision.

Overall Mrs. Brandt excels in all aspects of her job and goes above and beyond the typical counselor role. She is highly involved in all aspects of the school community and often drives improvement efforts. Due to her support, TPJHS continues to see improvement in student achievement in all areas: academic, behavioral and attendance. Way to go Mrs. Brandt!

post_text:
Each year, students in Ms. Goodwins DHI/CH class at Friendly Hills Elementary School learn an important lesson on empathy and understanding others.

For the last 17 years, Ms. Goodwin's students learn why some people (including children) might become homeless, and discuss the difficulties these individuals may face.

The students then work together to make gift bags that are complete with essential toiletries and a small gift. The gift bags are then delivered to the local Unity Home, who distributes them during the holidays.

The students learn that their small acts of kindness can make a difference in someone's lift. Way to go Hawks!

Students in Mrs. Possehl's 5th & 6th grade class at Friendly Hills Elementary School, got to spend a little time outdoors being creative today.

The class, who is currently reading the novel Hatchet, were tasked with building a shelter. In the book, the main character â€“ who is stranded in the Canadian wilderness â€“ must learn to survive.

Students who created shelters for the main character Brian, had to scavenging the area looking for natural materials, and then use them to construct lean-tos. The class will come back to their structures on Thursday to see which ones stood up to the elements. Way to go Hawks! Friendly Hills Elementary Association

post_text:
Congratulations to Twentynine Palms High School Teacher, Mrs. Jamie Anderson on her selection as a finalist for the California League of High Schools Region 10 Educator of the Year!

Jamie is one of 10 regional finalists selected from hundreds of nominations. The CLHS Region 10 consists of schools and educators in San Bernardino, Riverside, Inyo and Mono Counties.

Jamie is a home grown educator and graduate of Twentynine Palms High School. Jamie was nominated due to her outstanding work as co-lead of the TPHS WASC appeal visit that resulted in TPHS receiving an outstanding full 6-year accreditation status. Jamie has also taken on the leadership role as professional development coordinator, her involvement in bringing Dual Enrollment courses from Copper Mountain College to TPHS, her willingness to take on the challenge of working with at-risk students, serving as a class advisor, being an Advanced Placement teacher, and for the enormously positive effect she has had on her students and the TPHS community since joining the faculty.

post_text:
MUSD Governing Board Member L Hilary Slotta, was sworn in on November 13th for another 4-year term to the County Committee, by Ted Alejandre, San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schools.

The San Bernardino County Committee on School District Organization has responsibility for considering proposals to change the organization of one or more school districts. Organization includes altering the number of trustees, establishing trustee boundaries, school district boundary changes, and/or unification.

The County Committee consists of 11 members-two from each supervisorial district and one member elected at-large. Ms. Slotta is the at-large board member. Congratulations Mrs. Slotta!

Organization includes altering the number of trustees, establishing trustee boundaries, school district boundary changes, and/or unification.

The County Committee consists of 11 members-two from each supervisorial district and one member elected at-large. Ms. Slotta is the at-large board member. Congratulations Mrs. Slotta!

Did you know that November 13th is World Kindness Day? World Kindness Day is an international holiday that was formed in 1998, to promote kindness throughout the world.

The day is also known as Cardigan Day, and is a nod to the iconic childrenâ€™s television star, Fred Rogers, representing the kindness that the late Mr. Rogers spread.

Teachers at Palm Vista Elementary School came to school in their cardigans to show their togetherness in spreading kindness on campus. #WORLDKINDNESSDAY Palm Vista Panthers PTO

"One Judge, in one day, made one bad decision go away," said Superintendent Tom Baumgarten. Early this morning Superintendent Baumgarten traveled to Ventura County to speak out against the placement of a Registered Sex Offender in Joshua Tree, on behalf of residents in the Morongo Basin.

A Ventura County Superior Court judge ruled a convicted rapist Ross Wollschlager won't move to Joshua Tree. A huge victory for our Community!

post_text:
It's always great when students can gain real world experience along side academics in class. Students in Mr. Summers 4th grade class at Morongo Valley Elementary School are doing just that.

Mr. Summers has incorporated a Classroom Economy into his curriculum. Each student in the class has a job they had to apply for through an application, including letters of recommendation. Through this the students are learning to manage money, balance accounts, pay rent for the use of their desks, and even the consequences of getting tickets.

post_text:
Student in Mrs. Reid's 3rd grade class at Morongo Valley Elementary School got to have some fun with science, while testing their physical abilities. Students in the class had to formulate a hypothesis as to which gender could jump farther. Once they had done that, each student in the class had the opportunity to test out their jumping skills.

One student in the class, Amen Bendtsen was able to jump the farthest, even tying Principal Powell in length. Now that students are finished with the project, the class has created a running club on their own to improve their physical fitness even more. Way to go Morongo Valley!

San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schools
October 23, 2019 at 11:23 AM Â·

Record Number Of PBIS Programs From County To Be Honored
10-23-2019
SAN BERNARDINO â€“ A record 186 schools and programs from the West End and East Valley regions of San Bernardino County will receive recognition for their platinum, gold and silver awards from the California PBIS Coalition on Nov. 14. The California PBIS Coalition provides the awards for outstanding work with Positive Behavioral Interventions and Supports (PBIS) to improve the culture on campus for students and staff. The awards ceremony on Nov. 14 will be held at Way World Outreach Church in San Bernardino and will be hosted by San Bernardino County Superintendent of Schoolsâ€™ PBIS program.
https://www.sbcss.k12.ca.us/index.php/newsroom/newsroom-press-releases
